Award.AwardTitle: Making Opportunities for Computer Science and Computer Engineering Students (MOCS)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
To help address the critical shortage of students majoring in computer fields at the local, state, and national levels, this project is supporting 28 academically excellent and financially needy undergraduate students majoring in Computer Science and Computer Engineering (CSCE). New and transfer college students satisfying and maintaining the scholarship academic merit award criteria receive a scholarship of up to $4,800 per academic year for up to five years.

The project is expanding two prior NSF scholarship programs (DUE0323994 and 0728350) offered to engineering students. This project builds on successful outcomes and lessons learned by adapting two of the main features: mentorship for each scholarship recipient and a cohort living and learning community. New features in this project include heavy involvement by the local business community in the professional development of the scholarship recipients, and use of local Computer Science Teachers Association (CSTA) and the Tennessee Universal transfer program to recruit freshmen and transfer students into the program. The project includes supplemental instruction to improve retention rates and electronic professional portfolios to enhance career placement. Minority and female students are especially encouraged to apply. This program serves as a model for a living and learning community at the university and in the science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) higher educational environments. The goal is for 85% of the scholars to graduate with a computer science or computer engineering degree.

Intellectual Merit: The recruitment plan for freshman students draws on existing relationships with local businesses and partnerships with faculty, high school teachers, local community organizations, student ambassadors, and community colleges. Recruited scholars are being provided newly designed services and timely support geared towards their needs. Local and regional industry representatives serve as resources to enhance career exploration efforts and academic success of the scholarship recipients and to assist students in their transition to the workplace.

Broader Impacts: These scholarships allow academically talented and financially disadvantaged students to concentrate on their studies. Many activities proposed are being institutionalized and available to all students at the university. This program is helping to produce the technically educated workforce necessary for sustained regional economic growth for the region. Partnerships with local industry enhance job placement for students and outreach of the university into the community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project was proposed to support 28 talented but financially needy students (MOCS scholars). As the major outcome of the project, it has supported 48 scholars because some students left the program and/or were replaced by other students. Specifically, there are 37 scholars who have graduated with B.S. degree in Computer Science/Computer Engineering, 3 scholars who are expected to graduate in Fall 2020 or Spring 2021 in good academic standing, and 8 students dropped out from the college or change to other majors.

The supplemental instruction model worked very well in helping scholars to pass courses like CS 1 and CS2.  Effective tutoring was performed to retain students from the scholarship program and improve their academic performance. Tutoring was important to keep scholars connected especially when they start with internship and undergraduate research. Speaker/seminar series were organized to help MOCS scholars to understand academic requirements and industry expectation. Scholars have also learned real-world frontier knowledge through the speaker series. A new student success center director and a new outreach coordinator were hired by the college and helped to support services for scholars, faciliate student career development, and outreach high schools and connect with community colleges to recruit quality students. Agreement with several community colleges including Dalton State College, Chattanooga State Community College and Cleveland State Community College has been made to allow students at these schools to transfer to the University of Tennessee at Chattanooga and finish their bachelor’s degree in engineering or computer science. These cooperative alliances create an educated workforce that benefits our entire region. The project has positive impact on computer science and computer engineering enrollment. Our enrollment in computer science and computer engineering steadily grow every year since 2013. The retention rate of the cohort of scholars is 83.3%, which is much higher than national average. The program significantly helped to increase diversity by including female and minority students. Scholars who graduated have been employed by local and national business, such as UPS, Tennessee Valley Authority, Covenant Transport, UNUM, Asurion, Skuid, Mueller Co, FDM Group, Blue Cross Blue Shield of Tennessee, CO.LAB, Erlanger Hospital, or continued with graduate study at UTC.

Some scholars were highly engaged in undergraduate research by faculty mentors through different research projects in a variety of areas including cybersecurity, urban infrastructure monitoring, e-healthcare, connected vehicles, computational biology, virtual/augmented reality. Those research projects provided scholars with hands-on experience in interdisciplinary research. Those projects also offered opportunities for the scholars to interact with graduate students, researchers, engineers, and professionals in different background. Undergraduate research results were disseminated through project demos and paper presentations to communities in various institutional, local and national events, such as,   Technology Symposium of the College of Engineering and Computer Science, ReSEARCH Dialogues at UTC, Smart Cities Connect Conference & Expo and US Ignite Application Summit in Kansas City, MO, in March 2018, and Nation of Makers Conference (NOMCON) in Chattanooga Convention Center in June 2019.
